messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Computing list homomorphisms in geometric intersection graphs

Paper Abstract: A homomorphism from a graph Gùê∫G to a graph HùêªH is an edge-preserving mapping from V‚Äã(G)ùëâùê∫V(G) to V‚Äã(H)ùëâùêªV(H). Let HùêªH be a fixed graph with possible loops. In the list homomorphism problem, denoted by LHom(HùêªH), the instance is a graph Gùê∫G, whose every vertex is equipped with a subset of V‚Äã(H)ùëâùêªV(H), called list. We ask whether there exists a homomorphism from Gùê∫G to HùêªH, such that every vertex from Gùê∫G is mapped to a vertex from its list. We study the complexity of the LHom(HùêªH) problem in intersection graphs of various geometric objects. In particular, we are interested in answering the question for what graphs HùêªH and for what types of geometric objects, the LHom(HùêªH) problem can be solved in time subexponential in the number of vertices of the instance. We fully resolve this question for string graphs, i.e., intersection graphs of continuous curves in the plane. Quite surprisingly, it turns out that the dichotomy exactly coincides with the analogous dichotomy for graphs excluding a fixed path as an induced subgraph [Okrasa, RzƒÖ≈ºewski, STACS 2021]. Then we turn our attention to subclasses of string graphs, defined as intersections of fat objects. We observe that the (non)existence of subexponential-time algorithms in such classes is closely related to the size mrc‚Äã(H)mrcùêª\mathrm{mrc}(H) of a maximum reflexive clique in HùêªH, i.e., maximum number of pairwise adjacent vertices, each of which has a loop. We study the maximum value of mrc‚Äã(H)mrcùêª\mathrm{mrc}(H) that guarantees the existence of a subexponential-time algorithm for LHom(HùêªH) in intersection graphs of (i) convex fat objects, (ii) fat similarly-sized objects, and (iii) disks. In the first two cases we obtain optimal results, by giving matching algorithms and lower bounds. Finally, we discuss possible extensions of our results to weighted generalizations of LHom(HùêªH).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Geometric separation and exact solutions for the parameterized independent set problem on disk graphs",
        "Fine-grained complexity of coloring unit disks and balls",
        "On the complexity of the maximum cut problem",
        "EPTAS and subexponential algorithm for Maximum Clique on disk and unit ball graphs",
        "Optimality program in segment and string graphs",
        "Computational geometry column 62",
        "Every planar graph is the intersection graph of segments in the plane: extended abstract",
        "Unit disk graphs",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "A framework for exponential-time-hypothesis-tight algorithms and lower bounds in geometric intersection graphs",
        "Clique-based separators for geometric intersection graphs",
        "MAX-CUT and MAX-BISECTION are NP-hard on unit disk graphs",
        "The complexity of colouring problems on dense graphs",
        "The representation of a graph by set intersections",
        "List homomorphisms to reflexive graphs",
        "List homomorphisms and circular arc graphs",
        "Bi-arc graphs and the complexity of list homomorphisms",
        "Disk graphs: A short survey",
        "Finding, hitting and packing cycles in subexponential time on unit disk graphs",
        "ETH-tight algorithms for Long Path and Cycle on unit disk graphs",
        "Bidimensionality and geometric graphs",
        "Chapter 8 - interval graphs",
        "Planar graphs as L-intersection or L-contact graphs",
        "A dichotomy for minimum cost graph homomorphisms",
        "Representing graphs by disks and balls (a survey of recognition-complexity results)",
        "Broadcast scheduling algorithms for radio networks",
        "On the complexity of kùëòk-SAT",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Chapter 1 - graph theory for systems biology: Interval graphs, motifs, and pattern recognition",
        "Max-tolerance graphs as intersection graphs: cliques, cycles, and recognition",
        "On the exact complexity of Hamiltonian Cycle and qùëûq-Colouring in disk graphs",
        "Kontaktprobleme der konformen Abbildung",
        "Intersection graphs of segments",
        "String graphs. I. The number of critical nonstring graphs is infinite",
        "String graphs. II. Recognizing string graphs is NP-hard",
        "A special planar satisfiability problem and a consequence of its NP-completeness",
        "U-bubble model for mixed unit interval graphs and its applications: The MaxCut problem revisited",
        "Separators in region intersection graphs",
        "Representation of a finite graph by a set of intervals on the real line",
        "A separator theorem for planar graphs",
        "Efficient approximation schemes for geometric problems?",
        "On the optimality of planar and geometric approximation schemes",
        "Optimal parameterized algorithms for planar facility location problems using voronoi diagrams",
        "Near-optimal separators in string graphs",
        "Separators for sphere-packings and nearest neighbor graphs",
        "Full complexity classification of the list homomorphism problem for bounded-treewidth graphs",
        "Complexity of the list homomorphism problem in hereditary graph classes",
        "Subexponential algorithms for variants of the homomorphism problem in string graphs",
        "On variable-weighted exact satisfiability problems",
        "Robust algorithms for restricted domains",
        "Fixed Points, Nash Equilibria, and the Existential Theory of the Reals",
        "Geometric separator theorems and applications"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Computing list homomorphisms in geometric intersection graphs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
